_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: UV Fire/Hydrocarbon detectors and Personal 4 Gas Monitors

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document describes the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Chevron El Segundo Refinery. Included is a discussion of key hazardous substances used at the refinery, potential hazards they pose, as well as programs aimed at preventing release.  

Refinery operation is regulated by both Federal and State laws that strive to prevent major releases of hazardous materials. One of these regulations at the federal level is the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 (CAA). The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) is charged with overseeing the implementation of Section 112(r) of the CAA and also requires regulated facilities to periodically prepare and submit Risk Management Plans.  

The Chevron El Segundo RMP includes information regarding three federally regulated substances: anhydrous ammonia; aqueous ammonia; and flammable gases. The CAA also provides for public communication of this RMP to establish dialog between facilities and the surrounding community. 

The Environmental Protection Agency has listed specific elements to include in an RMP executive summary (40 CFR Part 68) as shared below.


1.1	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
One of the key purposes of the prevention program is to establish a process safety management system within regulated facilities.  The refinery routinely analyzes potential hazards and takes proactive steps to ensure these risks are mitigated. Chevron El Segundo first established a Process Safety Management (PSM) program in the early 1990s as part of its OSHA compliance efforts. The EPA recognizes this OSHA mandated program in the RMP regulations. Below the key elements covered under the PSM program.

	Training facility operators and maintenance personnel
	Performing hazards analyses on new and existing plants at periodic intervals
	Ensuring operating procedures are in place and maintained
	Ensuring the mechanical integrity of operating equipment through routine maintenance and ins

pection programs
	Investigating all major incidents
	Maintaining Process Safety Information
	Managing change under a Management of Change (MOC) process
	Completing Pre-startup Safety Reviews before commissioning plant and equipment
	Conducting periodic Compliance Audits
	Ensuring employee participation (EP) in aspects of the PSM program
	Hot Work Permit process as part of managing safe work
	Including contractors in the PSM program

The refinery has its own fire department.  Fire fighters and emergency medical technicians are on site 24 hours a day and trained to provide rapid, first response to an incident.  In addition, the refinery has an emergency response plan and works closely with the El Segundo Fire Department on the response to fires or releases, public sheltering and the coordination of other support service providers such as police or paramedics.  The main city fire station is approximately half of a mile from the refinery. 


1.2	The Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

Toxic Substances
The RMP covers both anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. Ammonia is a byproduct generated in the removal of nitrogen from crude oil.

Flammables
The refinery contains light, flammable hydrocarbon gases ranging from methane to pentane. 


1.3	RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis

This section describes the "worst-case release" and "alternative case release" scenarios for toxic and flammable substances at the facility.

A "worst-case release" is defined by the EPA as a release of the entire, largest single-point quantity in a scenario that would create the largest offsite consequence under worst-case atmospheric conditions and rapid release rate. Since these worst-cases scenarios are based on extreme conditions, they are highly unlikely to occur.  

The "alternative-case" scenarios, although still unlikely, represent more realistic outcomes that could occur under abnormal conditions.  One alternative release scenario is analyzed for each of the toxic substan

ces and for all flammable substances.


1.4	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps
  
The refinery has implemented and maintained an active OSHA PSM program since the early 1990's.  The EPA recognized this OSHA process in the development of the RMP program.  The OSHA program satisfies the RMP requirements for a prevention program.  

Additional prevention steps specific to ammonia include refinery specifications for new piping and equipment in ammonia service.  The specifications include features such as having high reliability valves, minimal connections, using heat treated metals in vessels, selection of metals resistant to embrittlement during auto-refrigeration, and more isolation valves on liquid lines.


1.5	Five Year Accident History
No reportable incidents.


1.6	Emergency Response Program

El Segundo has a 24/7 staffed fire department.  Additionally, an emergency response plan is in place to address the following:

	Specific actions to take in a response to an accidental release of hazardous chemicals;
	Procedures for informing the public and the local agencies;
	Information on emergency health care;
	Information on how to communicate with the local emergency response agency;
	Identification, maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency equipment; and
	Training information.

Note that the refinery fire fighters and emergency response personnel routinely drill and train to maintain their skills in emergency response.


1.7	Planned Changes to Improve Safety (Continual Improvement Efforts)
Continual improvement efforts to sustain a healthy safety culture and maintain focus on safeguard health which are relevant to the RMP:
	Ongoing Safeguard awareness engagement program
	Assurance programs to understand health of safeguards and mitigate gaps
	Growing a Human Performance culture in the refinery


1.8	Changes from Previous RMP Submittal
Anhydrous Ammonia Risk Reduction project: The refinery recently completed a project th

at has reduced the inventory of anhydrous ammonia by 86%. Total anhydrous ammonia inventory within the ammonia plant was reduced due to the project decreasing total anhydrous ammonia inventory below the reporting threshold of 10,000 pounds.
